page.title: 02Buildings in Dunmow
page.content: Many of the buildings are very old in design. The Town Hall was built in the Sixteenth Century and is a fine example of an oak timbered building with walls which were originally made of wattle and daub. The floor above ground level is partly supported by jetties. Another old building is the Saracens Cottage which shows the arms of the Fitzwalter and Maynard families on the pargetting. Some of the offices have pillars with canopies over the front doors. The buildings are close together. Most windows are of the sash type with mullions between the panes. Some of the new houses have double glazed windows and doors and are insulated which helps stop the heat escaping through the walls and ceilings. Roofs are made of tiles, slates or thatched with straw.
